thread.title: On The Rocks launches food and alcohol home delivery company in Auckland | Stuff.co.nz
thread.title_full: On The Rocks launches food and alcohol home delivery company in Auckland | Stuff.co.nz

author: Tom Carnegie
title: On The Rocks launches food and alcohol home delivery company in Auckland | Stuff.co.nz
text:
On The Rocks launches food and alcohol home delivery company in Auckland TOM CARNEGIE Last updated 16:38, February 1 2017 TOM CARNEGIE/FAIRFAX NZ. 
On The Rocks founders Tejas Dalvi, left, and Joseph Chacko say their delivery website officially launches on February 6. 
A new Auckland company will deliver McDonald's right to your door, as long as you order some booze to go with it. 
On The Rocks is a new alcohol and food home delivery company operating in the suburbs of central and east Auckland. 
Its website lists a number of fast food options that can be ordered, including kebabs, pizza and McDonald's. 123RF 
A McDonald's spokesperson says the company is not aware On The Rocks plans to deliver its food. 
There is a catch to ordering the food however, as it can only be ordered as an addition to alcohol. 
READ MORE: * Alcohol delivery service vows to be back in business soon 
Joseph Chacko, On The Rocks managing director, said only alcohol could be ordered on its own. 
"It would not be financially viable for us to just deliver the food on its own," Chacko said.â€‹ 
On The Rocks is the second alcohol home delivery company to start operating in Auckland in recent months. 
Bevee, founded by Jack Price, Jordan Jennings and Hugh Blackburne, launched in central Auckland suburbs in November 2016. 
Nicki Jackson, executive director of Alcohol Healthwatch, said a number of factors concern her about alcohol home delivery companies. Ad Feedback 
"We are concerned for the communities that this organisation wants to deliver alcohol to," Jackson said. 
"The evidence points quite clearly that these communities will have an increase in assault and drink driving incidents because of this increase in availability," Jackson said. 
She said she was concerned that On The Rocks did not have an age identification check to enter its website. 
"When you look at other types of sites similar to this one, they at least have that gateway. 
"I think we need to keep a close eye on these companies, particularly with the potential sale of alcohol to minors," Jackson said. 
Chacko said its delivery drivers had all completed an alcohol management course. 
He said he had met with police and Auckland Council to talk through their concerns and all drivers had completed an alcohol management course. 
If a customer was intoxicated they would not hand over alcohol, he said. 
In 2015 Wellington booze delivery company Quenched faced huge backlash and closed its website just a week after launching. 
It faced criticism over its slogans which included, "Delivering happiness", "Need booze quick? We'll have it to your door in 45 minutes. Don't stop the party at your place early, we are here to help". 
On The Rocks said it delivered within two hours. 
A McDonald's spokesman said it was not aware On The Rocks would be delivering its food. 
"Aside from Menulog, which is part of our home delivery trial in New Lynn and Glenfield, we don't have any formal relationship with delivery companies," the spokesman said. 
He said On The Rocks was using McDonald's images on its website without permission. 
"While businesses are able to offer the delivery service, they are not allowed to use our trademarks in their marketing. 
"Typically we would ask businesses using our trademarks without our permission to stop doing so," the spokesman said. 
The spokesman said he was not aware of any other company selling alcohol alongside McDonald's in New Zealand. 
"In some countries, mainly Europe, McDonald's sells beer, but nothing in New Zealand," he said. 
Chacko said the company had an off-site liquor licence. 
"It is my understanding we do not need a license for the food delivery as we are not making it. 
"All food is bagged by the companies who produce it and we just act as a third party when we deliver it," Chacko said. 
Police have been approached for comment. - Stuff
